required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Supplement Intake in Infertile Men;the Effect on Sperm Parameters,Fertilization Rate and Embryo Quality
clinical_study.official_title: Vitamins ,Minerals and Amino Acids Supplement Intake in Infertile Men;the Effect on Sperm Parameters,Fertilization Rate and Embryo Quality. A Double Blind Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The vitamin,minerals and amino acid supplementation for 3 months will improve the semen parameters,fertilization rate and embryo quality in subfertile men undergoing IVF treatment

detailed_description.textblock: With the supplement intake containing amino acids, vitamins and minerals designed to improve sperm parameters, the couples undergoing IVF treatment will benefit as the change and improvement of sperm parameters will increase the fertilization rate and improve the embryo quality thus allowing shorter time for pregnancy achievement and less frustration with long duration of treatments

primary_outcome.description: Men suffering from a "male factor" problem and after one failed IVF treatment will be given the supplement for 3 months after which the sperm parametrs will be evaluated and compared to pre-supplement data and later the embryo quality and fertilization rate will reviewed analyzed and compared

intervention.description: men will receive the vitamale dietary supplement compared to a sham pill
intervention.other_name: amino acid minerals and vitamin supplement

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- healthy male age 20-50
- at least one IVF cycle without pregnancy
- sperm parameters:
- Oligospermia 5-20*106
- Teratospermia 6-14% normal forms
- Asthenospermia <30% motility
Exclusion Criteria:
- female factor infertility
- age > 50 or under 20
- testicular problem on physical examination
- history of malignancy and /or chemotherapy
- usage of antiandrogen/testosterone
- history of drug abuse/alcohol
- a known endocrinological problem
- current STD or genitourinary infection
- Retrograde Ejaculation
- Y chromosome microdeletion
- Karyotype abnormalities
